title: RCServo extruder - 96 grams direct drive
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In pursuit to make a lighter direct drive extruder I propose you this extruder based on a RC servo. We managed a 96 gr. extruder with everything on - servo motor, electronics, Mk7 gear, bearing, axes, spring, etc. - and 15.5 kg-cm torque (3.5 more than nema 17 torque).

We use this extruder on a self made corexy printer with fixed fans - see the crossflow aproach https://ultimaker.com/en/community/4890-the-crossflow-fan-approach?page=1&sort= .

Also the extruder is designed to be fast/easy be replaced with laser, pen or spindle.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer

Infill:

25-50%

Notes:

We suggest to print in PETG or ABS.

description.header: What You Will Need to Build
description.text:
RCServo Bill Of Material

Complete Bill of Material – 08.31.2017

Mechanics

1x RC standard servo, we use FT5316M;
2x M105ZZ bearing;
1x Mk7 gear;
1x E3D v6 hotend;
1x M3x20 mm screw;
1x M3x40 mm screw;
2x M4x33 mm screw;
1x 8x12 mm extruder spring;
1x M3 special nuts ;
52 mm PTFE 4mm diameter;
20 mm stainless steel 5mm diameter;
1x Complete set of printed parts;

Electronics

1x AS5040 encoder hall sensor ;
1x AS5000-MD6H-2 Magnet;
2x 220 ohmi smd resistor;
1x 2k7 ohmi smd resistor;
1x 100 nF smd capacitor;
1x 2200 nF smd capacitor;
1x DRV8838 single DC brushed motor driver;
1x D24V22F6 voltage regulator;
1x Arduino Nano;

Note: Next version, now in development, will use Attiny 85.

1.Modify the servo

You need to modify the servo for continuous rotation. For standard servo FT5316M you need to remove the pin on the final gear. Just pull up with a pliers. After that remove the electronics and the potentiometer. Now you need to add feedback to your servo. A very good tutorial you can find here. - Thank you Andrey Pozhogin (dccharacter). I have added the eagle files that I used.

Finally you have a powerful DC geared motor with quadrature feedback. To use this on a 3d printer we need to make a compatible A4988 pin to pin driver.

We will make this with an Arduino Nano, a DRV8838 single DC brushed motor driver and D24V22F6 voltage regulator.

2.Build the mechanics part.

First you will print all the part in ABS or PETG. The settings are the usual, 0.4 mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layers, 25-50% infill, etc.

Because we have a crossflow fan, who cools down everything, we print the parts in black PLA. If it is somebody interested, I can design the RCServo extruder with support for hot end fan and filament fan.

Next you will make the servo motor to Mk7 gear adapter. This is a 5 mm diameter, 20 mm long stainless steel pin with 5 mm long M3 thread.

Press one bearing in extruder body. Next set up the extruder body, servomotor with 5 mm pin attached and Mk7 gear.

Press a 5 mm diameter, 12 mm long Al pin to second bearing and press to extruder arm. Set up the arm on the extruder body with M3 screw. Adjust the extruder spring with special M3 nuts.

Now you can glue the extruder wire support on top left extruder. I printed the extruder apart from wire support to have a good base to print the extruder.

Insert the PTFE tube into the hotend and then into the extruder and adjust the length of the tube to fit it.

Now mount the extruder on the xy carriage and make the hotend connections.

Note: If somebody needs another type of fixing the extruder/hotend to carriage, I can design it. Also I can provide parts or even a complete extruder.

3. Build the servo driver

We will show how to make this driver based on Arduino Nano. This is the actual RCServo extruder we use right now, but we have in development a lighter and simpler driver based on Attiny 85.

Our printer is powered by Ramps 1.4. We removed the extruder A4988 driver and replaced it with our driver. The driver will use both extruder space on Ramp. Next development based on Attiny 85 will be small enough to fit in on one extruder driver.

Our driver will receive the STEP and DIR signal from the Ramps and will drive the servo motor based on a PID solution.

We have added for download, the board we use to replace the stepper extruder driver.

The firmware dcservo.ino we use is based on beautiful solution of Miguel Sanchez - Thank you- and modified to suite our needs.
To upload, to Arduino Nano, the firmware you must install Arduino IDE. The upload process is well documented on the web.

Next don't forget to tune up the PID parameters:

  • setup the equivalent step/mm for extruder on Marlin firmware with M92 Ennn command. In our case M92 E32. Store the value to eprom with M500 command. Also you can setup step/mm in configuration.h and upload to controller;
  • connect a pc/laptop, with Arduino IDE installed, to Arduino Nano and start serial monitor with 115200 bauds;
  • start power to the printer and make sure you don't have filament loaded;
  • on serial monitor type A and enter. On monitor you will see actual position, PID output and target position each second;
  • type X50 enter and watch the actual position value. Increase P gain by typing Pvalue enter until servomotor start oscillate around X position (change X after each P change);
  • increase D gain (change X after each D change) until servomotor stop oscillate;
  • repeat setup P and D until increasing D do not stop oscillation. Set P and D to last stable value. Usual D is 10 to 20 time P;
  • increase I gain to remove small error on position. Usual I is about 10% of P (small is better);
  • type W enter to save values to eprom;
  • disconnect laptop from Arduino Nano.

You need to fine tuning the equivalent step/mm for extruder, as usual for extruders, after PID tuning;

Congratulations, you can start to print with your new 96 grams direct drive extruder.

3DBenchy printed with following settings: speed 55 mm/sec, retraction 0.5 mm / 25 mm/sec, nozzle 0.4 mm, 0.2 mm layer, black PLA. Good enough.

comments.text: Another 10 days of printing with my RCServo extruder. I have printed at least 8 hours/day, every day and all worked well. The longest single printed parts took about 6 hours. So for now is it fine. All printing was done at 60 mm/sec, with PLA and PETG.

description.text:
Shooter ready, stand by......

Huge ass flared magwell for AR15/M4 rifles, designed for competitve environment where crazy accessories are cool, even cooler if it helps your reloads.

Features:

  • Flared magwell in a funnel shape for easier magazine insertion.
  • Approx. 200% opening area compared to normal magwell.
  • 5 degree lower angle to prevent collision to your fingers if you use "beer can grip".
  • Cutout section to accommodate aftermarket trigger guards.
  • Fits most magazines...... probably, test and verify before use! (Nope, no drums.)
  • For use with forged style AR15 lower receiver, modeled after AR-15 Lower, will fit airsoft rifle if the receiver size is same as real ones (Pictured above).

Notes:

  • 2x M3x5mm grub screws required for this magwell to secure, which WILL scratch and/or mar your receiver.

UPDATE: 12 Oct 2017 - Added "V5 Wedge" version as requested, due to change of screw locations to accommodate the wedges, the main body of original V4 will not fit. You may need longer grub screws (M3x6mm) to engage the dimples inside the wedges.
Please be informed I have not printed and tested this version myself.

description.text:
This is a main board support for Kurzweil K2600 synthesizer. It supports the main electronics board in the bottom metal frame. The original supports almost all broke due to age and/or handling. They get mechanically overloaded as they were under-designed. The board was poorly supported and I wouldn't have been able to sleep knowing that it's straining like that :)

The original broken parts removed from the keyboard approximately resemble RICHCO part EHCBS-5-01, but the dimensions don't fully agree. The RICHCO part would likely work, had you replaced all of them so that their dimensions would match. I had the keyboard apart and didn't want to wait for replacements to arrive. I don't want to handle it any more than necessary - it's a 70+lb beast.

The 3D model is made to the dimensions of the "Kurzweil" part, not the RICHCO part, and slightly modified for better printability. The end of the pin may require a dedicated support to bond it to the bed and prevent lifting.

While this model has most of the shape of the original, and thus might fail in a similar fashion, I'm not intending to move my keyboard much and expect the part to last. Should it fail again, or if you expect to transport your gear a lot, some cross-sections should be enlarged to make it stronger.

Note: I didn't wait for the Nylon to be fully dried before printing - the prints I took the pictures of are merely passable.

  • First layer: 0.6mm extrusion width, 0.15mm height, 240C/100C.

description.text: Supercooling for your E3D V6! A 40mm heatsink fan and FOUR 40mm print cooling fans! Very aerodynamic and sleek, this should flow exceedingly well. This snaps on to the heatsink quite tight! Made for my gearbest E3D V6 clone, but should also fit originals! The V6 heatsink shaft diameter is 22.27mm and the V6 heatsink height is 26.15mm. A bit of refining went into the inside to optimize flow and onto the outside to match aesthetically. Everything is supposed to be tight and solid once it's in its desired location. The standard compressor turbines are for the heatsink cooling and the High Compression turbines are for the print cooling fans. I would recommend printing the mount and the arms solid but the "Twin Tornado" and compressor turbines with two perimeters and no infill.

description.text: He decidido agrupar en un único post todos los pasos necesarios para cambiar de varillas roscadas a husillos en cualquier impresora cartesiana ( en mi caso tengo la Prusa i3 Hephestos de bq )

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

+50%

Notes:

Todas las piezas han sido impresas con PLA

Lo coloco en primer lugar porque he elegido Aliexpress y el tiempo de envío es significativo. Necesitamos:

-Husillos de 8mm y tuerca x2 (https://goo.gl/EfjSmP), he elegido el modelo THSL-300-8D

-Acoples flexibles x2 (https://goo.gl/TLdXns)

-Rodamientos lineales LM8UU x4 (https://goo.gl/Ri5YWs) Yo compré 12 y aproveché para cambiar también los del carro del extrusor y tener repuestos

-Rodamientos 608ZZ x2 (https://goo.gl/CQRkuu)

Tendremos que cambiar las piezas donde antes estaban colocadas las varillas roscadas. He usado las piezas subidas por el compañero @Txispas, publicadas en el siguiente enlace: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:916877

Y para conseguir algo más de estabilidad he hecho uso de los rodamientos lineales, insertándolos en una pieza modificada para los tirantes que le puse. Original de @jopoma en https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1595059

Así como las propias piezas de los tirantes subidas a este post.

También tendremos que cambiar el Marlin, porque ahora por cada vuelta de motor no subirá los mismos milimetros que antes. Explico brevemente como hacerlo:

  1. Instalar Arduino 1.6.7 en C:\Program Files (x86)\Arduino . IMPORTANTE copiar la carpeta Arduino en C:\ , en la raíz
    ( https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/OldSoftwareReleases#previous )
  2. Instalar Make-3.8.1 en C:\Program Files (x86)\GnuWin32
    ( https://goo.gl/mv1pJK )
    (Yo los he instalado ejecutándolos como administrador, para evitar problemas)

Y ahora para modificar el Marlin:

  1. Descargamos la última versión del GitHub de bq (https://github.com/bq/Marlin)
  2. Extraemos el .zip y nos vamos a \Marlin\libraries\SdFat y cortamos todos los archivos. Los pegamos en \Marlin
  3. Ahora vamos a \Marlin\config\hephestos o a cualquier otro modelo de impresora, y cortamos solo Configuration.h y Configuration_adv.h, el Makefile NO!
  4. Abrimos con cualquier editor de texto Configuration.h y buscamos #define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT , editando el tercer parámetro.
    En mi caso lo cambié de 4000 a 400, usando el simple cálculo de 200x16/8 , donde 200 son los pasos por vuelta de mis paso a paso, 1/16 la resolución del pololu y 8 el paso de rosca de mi husillo. Podéis usar también http://www.prusaprinters.org/calculator/ para calcularlo.
  5. Por último, con la impresora conectada al ordenador, nos vamos a la carpeta origen y ejecutamos nuevamente como administrador make.cmd y seguimos el instalador.

Nota: para ver el puerto COM puede hacerse desde Administrador de dispositivos o con Simplify3D, aunque normalmente es el COM3

Intentaré dejar por aquí subidos los .hex que he utilizado, pero por el momento dejo la carpeta entera de la versión 2.5.1 para que lo compiléis a la impresora, realizando los primeros pasos 1, 2 y el último.

También podéis compilar los Marlin directamente desde Cura sin necesidad de descargar nada.

Carpeta firmware bq 2.5.1 sin cama caliente: https://goo.gl/zda1oZ
Carpeta firmware bq 2.5.1 con cama caliente: https://goo.gl/zHnjjT

Marlin.hex bq 2.5.1 sin cama: https://goo.gl/u1j2wq
Marlin.hex bq 2.5.1 con cama: https://goo.gl/nwpnxs

title: LWC DIY Taser 20 000volts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
DANGER DANGER! High Voltage, when we touch, when we kiss..........:D
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qt6uMf6LlX0

Howto step by step video: ( in the video I said "counter clockwise" of course I meant CLOCKWISE ;) )
https://youtu.be/d-Ju--gEnRg

Ever wanted to have one of those but never bought one. Totally overpriced for whats inside if you buy them online.

The heart of a Taser is a simple high voltage Generator, you can buy them for 2 Euros/ USD!! and they can deliver up to 20 000 Volts. ( The cheap price comes of course with a down side, the high voltage generators can die on you any time soon, out of 4 only one survived). So if you wanna produce some ozone gas or like to walk around in dark alleys at night ( to make sparkling sounds) this could be the right thing for you.

WARNING This is not a toy, playing around with 20kV can be very very painful or even deadly ( if you fall over and hit your head really bad or drive a car and crash into another)

The internal battery can be charged comfortably per micro USB.

!!VERY IMPORTANT!! A longer spark looks much cooler BUT the rather short distance between the two probes in this mod is absolutely necessary! Dont change the GAP!! The voltage generator is producing a very high voltage, this includes high pressure. If you put the probes further apart there will be a lot more pressure which will cause the high pressure cascade to fail and the high voltage generator will stop working!! ( believe me I killed 2 high voltage generator evenso it seems to be working ok in the beginning)

UPDATE from11.09.2017
Thanks to mussy who reminded me to add a absolutely necessary feature, a safty sliding switch. I also updated the schematic. Add the switch to the primary side! ( not the charging circuit ;) )

I tried the taser on a self test and honestly I am a bit disappointed. I tried it on my arm and my left thight. I mean it stings when the spark hits the surface and also there is some skin irritation afterwards, but worlds off to knock me out or make me unable to move. On direct kontakt on the skin the muscle underneath tension up pretty hard and there is some movement but even less pain than being hit by sparks coming from the taser. So watching all those videos on youtube where teens laying on the ground moaning around doesnt make sense next to overreacting and adding drama. Still its pretty cool :D
( a real taser who is shooting two probes is a way different thing, because the voltage travels a much longer distance from one to the other probe causing severe pain and cramps in between them)

This build is pretty easy and only needs a few parts:

The heart of every taser, a high voltage generator:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/New-DC-3V-6V-bis-400kV-400000V-Boost-Step-up-Power-Module-High-Voltage-Generator/32797581971.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.7JZJaS

A push button 12x12mm:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/B3F-20PCS-Tactile-Push-Button-Switch-Momentary-12-12-7-3MM-Micro-switch-button-20PCS-4/32762266462.html

A rechargeable 18650 Lithium Ion battery:
DONT! buy a cheap china battery, they are mostly lying about capacity and protective circuit! I would recommend buying a genuine branded Battery from a know producer:

https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B01C7YBXRU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

A lithium Ion USB charging board:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-lot-TP4056-1A-Lipo-Battery-Charging-Board-Charger-Module-lithium-battery-DIY-MICRO-Port-Mike/32651302113.html

A saftey switch from preventing the taser to spit sparks if the push button is pressed unwanted:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/20Pcs-SS12D11-toggle-switch-3Pins-Curved-needle-1P2T-handle-high-5mm-spacing-of-4-7mm-3A/32815517966.html

Two nails, or screws which will make the points where the spark jumps from one side to the other on top of the taser.

Soldering iron,Heatglue gun, superglue,sandpaper,cable for wiring

description.text: A mount to hold a Google Home and cable using the (UK) wall plug, to save space or hold your Home off the ground/counter.

This holder is primarily for larger rolls up to 10kg as seen in the picture. This is the third iteration as it started larger and more complicated specifically for 10kg rolls, but I ended up simplifying it and making it more universal so it can fit rolls as small as 1kg as well. It can also be printed by those with smaller printers. You will need a minimum build area of 250mm in one direction. It will use 345 gram of plastic total for all pieces if printed with the supplied settings. The cost of materials is about $10 plus your plastic. If using a 10kg roll, it is recommended to print the roller end caps in PC but PLA or ABS will work just fine too if that's what you have available. The holder is extremely durable and has been tested to 200 pounds (me standing on the rollers) and should last for many years. The 2 non printed parts you will need are 608zz bearings and a length of 1 inch or 25.5mm rod in diameter. I used 1 inch diameter wood rod that can be bought at most hardware stores in lengths of 6 feet for about $6. But you may choose to use metal or PVC. You will need 4 bearings and the quality of the bearings is of utmost importance, especially if this is for a 10kg roll. I have tested many bearings including ceramic and these are the bearings that I chose and tested to have the least amount of friction.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072JZ1M5N/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.30

Infill:

30

Notes:

Print the base halves at .3 layer, 2 perimeter, and 30% rectilinear infill. Supports No
Print the base clamps at .3 layer, 2 perimeter, and 15% rectilinear infill. Supports No
Print the roller ends at .2 layer, 2 perimeter, and solid 100% infill. Supports Yes.

Instructions:

First you will need to print 2 base halves, 2 base clamps, and 4 roller end caps.
You will need to cut two lengths of rod to 9 and 1/8" inch or 231mm. If you can not make a precision cut to this length, it will be better for you to error on being too short. They could be short as 8 and 3/4" inch and still work fine by simply extending the rod end caps further out on the rod instead of putting them on flush. If you cut the rod too long, it will not work as the holders front and back clamps are at a fixed distance. So if you want to play it safe then just make your cuts at 9" inches or 227mm. Once you have printed your parts and cut the rods to length, install the rod end caps. If your extrusion is correct they should be snug but still able to easily slide them on. It is also important that you do not have large seam lines on the end caps. It is a good idea to sand them off if you do. A raised seam can cause significant drag on a 10kg spool. Next, press fit your bearings into the base halves. You may need to clean up the holes in the base halves a little first since no support was used. Now stand both base halves up on end and place the rods in the bearings between the halves. Take one of the end clamps and align the clamp with the base notch cut outs. Using your hand in a fast motion, quickly give the clamp a solid smack and it will lock on to the base half. Now do the same to the other 3 corners. Now that it is assembled you can adjust the slack between the rod end caps and the bearings by sliding the caps further off the rod. Give each roller a quick spin until you're happy with the adjustment. If you wish, at this point you could put a little super glue along the seam of the roller cap and the roller itself to keep the cap from moving and changing the length of your roller. You will notice holes on the corners of the base halves. These can be used to anchor the holder to a table or shelf with screws or suction cups if you wish. Then there are 4 holes at the top of the base halves. These are a safety measure for 1kg rolls that print from above your printer. You can use the two rear holes to tie a piece of string from the corners going through your filament spools center hub and this will prevent your roll being pulled off the holder and falling on your printer in the event of a filament tangle.
Feel free to scale this, remix it, or make it more to your liking.

Happy printing!

This is a simple part to space the stepper motor appropriately for the pulleys of the small X,Y belts on an Ultimaker (revised UMO+). The belts were rubbing against the plywood and there was no way to align them properly with the pulleys.

I printed them in PET so as to withstand the maximum stepper motor temperatures (do not print them in PLA!).

The default spacing is 15mm but you can change it with the customizer, along with all other useful variables.

description.text:
A collection of all purpose wedges. These aren’t done with OpenSCAD but with FreeCAD, but are rounded (filleted).
There are four versions of FreeCAD files

  • A wedge with a sharp edge, to be printed lying flat
  • A blunt wedge, to be printed lying flat
  • A wedge with a sharp edge, to be printed upright
  • A blunt wedge, to be printed upright

There are a few ready made STL files:

  • One to prop open a window (Fensterkeil.stl)
  • Two versions to prop open a patio door (that has quite a bit of ground clearance)
  • Two without a specific purpose in mind

The idea is that you take the FreeCAD files and change the size to what you need. It’s a bit harder than with my dial-a-wedge, sorry. Do it like this:

  • Download FreeCAD and get it running
  • Load one of the fcstd FreeCAD files.
  • In the tree view, double click on “Sizes”. You should see the spreadsheet
  • Change the values to what you want. Make sure to keep the = and mm.
  • Go back to, wlog, the upright_wedge view. Tab at the bottom.
  • Check that the shown shape looks OK. There are view controls at the top
  • Check that in the tree view there are no exclamation marks as warnings
  • If there are problems, it’s easiest to close without saving and to try again. Change fewer values, and only by small amounts.
  • If the wedge looks good, select the last item in the tree view. The wedge should turn green in the main view.
  • Look for the dropdown in the tool bar and select “Mesh Design”
  • You should now have a “Meshes” menu. Select “Create mesh from shape …”
  • I have to select the “Standard” radio button. “Mefisto” produces empty meshes.
  • Click OK
  • There should be a “fillet (Meshed)” or similar item in the tree view. Select it.
  • Click on the “Export a mesh to file” icon, enter a file name, select the file type (STL or OBJ) and click “OK”,
  • Et voilà, you’re done. You have finished your first FreeCAD lesson and can now go ahead and slice and print your customized wedge.

title: Ncase M1 - EK D5 Pump/Res Mount

description.text:
Summary

This is a mount for a EK D5 pump in the Ncase M1, the best small form factor case ever, for use with custom water cooling.

Features

  • Reuses the internal SSD mounting holes
  • Perfect fitment
  • Secure & easy to remove
  • Easy print

Requirements

  • 3x M3 nuts
  • 3.5mm drill bit
  • 4x M4 12mm screws (from the EK D5 pump)
  • 3x SSD M3 screws with rubber inserts (from the Ncase M1)

Printing

Print in PETG or ABS if possible. PLA will work because it is not directly exposed to any heat, but will still not last as long.

Use 0.24mm layer height or higher for better strength.

Use 4 perimeters! Because that is where most of the force is. 3 top/bottom layers should be enough.

30% or higher infill.

Instructions

  1. Drill out the M3 holes with a 3.5mm drill bit
  2. Insert the three M3 nuts. This will be tight, so use a pair of pliers if needed
  3. Put on the three rubber-inserted M3 screws
  4. Screw the mounting plate to the D5 pump bracket, with four M4 screws
  5. Slot the entire assembly to the front frame of the case, where the internal SSD is supposed to go

author: wywywywy

description.text:
A derivative for 40mm fans that plug onto an UMO RAMPS board. I just was no more able to find the source though (thingiverse "infinite" listing is horrible), so let me know if ever you stumble upon it! :/

Install one to push air against the stepper drivers, and the second fan to extract it.

There are variants with fins instead of the second fan, and you can tune the fan sizes in the provided openscad file.

It would much better be laser cut than 3D printed in fact (just lay the fans flat, and extract a DXF/contour from the STL or scad file). I wanted to mill it in MDF, but so far I cowardly 3D printed it instead... and it takes ages!

In this regard (3D printing), I would have better re-used a one piece design like the old (and somehow flimsy) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28498 (does the job and is easy to print), or a waay more recent one like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1147173 They both would be faster to 3D print.

Hope you enjoy this miniature of King of Tokyo. Let me know what you guys think!

Special thanks to my buddy Nick de Waal for painting!

Want more?

I'm currently working on other monsters as well. Please let me know if you like this!
I'm still new to 3D designing so it will take some time to complete all of them.

The flat part, the lever, might need some adjustment, because it's a first version.

And that's it.
It works now with my RC cars and Rx-43d-1 receiver with lights management.

title: Sesame Smart Lock: Compatibility Bracket for Tiny Knobs and Riser Mount

description.text:
The Sesame Smart Lock works with most locks with a knob. But what if your knobs are too small and risen in a narrow way that its hard to mount the Sesame Smart Lock even with the included metal compatibility bracket? What if you have a very irregular door? A few minutes of 3D printing solves this!

I happened to live in an apartment with one of these issues, so I designed a very simple riser for the 3M Command Strips to be mounted with the Sesame Smart Lock. I also made a simple knob expander measured so there's little give once put over that is customizable on Tinkercad. This ensures that you'll have no problems as it spins. The risers are almost the minimum length possible to fit the dimensions of the 3M Command strips. Your Sesame Smart Lock will also come with a metal rising mount.

I've been using this design for half a year with zero problems at all.

Your knob or door may be different so it is publicly available for remix on Tinkercad. I will also help with requests if measurements are made.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/chBfFFLxzQA

title: Funko Pop! Figure Shelf Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My daughter needed a better way to display her Funko Pop figures; her deep shelf was obscuring most of them. I had some spare wooden battens 2.5"x3/4" that were wide enough to display one figure deep so I made these brackets.

The brackets are not designed to take heavy loads and should be mounted with the wall fixing at the top to reduce the amount of leverage. The opening is 70mm x 20mm and fits my battens loosely - your mileage may vary. I have provided both left and right models with enclosed and open ends. The open ended models can be used to support the middle of long shelves.

title: PP3D UP Plus extruder cooling duct for hot printing (ABS, PETG, PC..)

description.text:
The stock PP3DP "wind barrier" for UP Plus, UP Plus2 and some similar printers (Afinia etc.) is ok for PLA but for ABS the air passing trough "closed flap" makes ABS prints warp. There's a nice upgrade PP3DP Up Plus redesigned wind barrier by PrintMo that I have bin using for years and that works like a charm for ABS. Now if you want to move away from ABS and go bit hotter and print PETG, PC, Nylon.. (all possible since we do have an all metal hotend here!) the small axial fan that cools the cold end of the extruder (the throat) is not enough and for too hot or very long prints you can have jams in the throat, underextrusion etc. This is why I redesigned the piece from cratch for a radial fan. Radial fan can push more air at higher speed then regular axial fan, they are easy to get (~5$ on ebay delivered) and they do not produce much more noise then the provided fan. You can even get some "super strong" ones that can push huge amount of air that you can slow down with 7809 or 7805 to get the quiet and still have huge amount of air going trough...

I intentionally didn't add any mounting arms for the fan mount as I prefer to just use hot glue (hotsnot, hotmelt glue, whatever you call it) to link the duct and the fan. This way the hot glue seals the hole between duct and fan and provides some vibration dampening. It's still easy to remove fan from duct if need arises.

The exit hole of the duct is projecting air at 30°-45° upwards so it does not interfere with the print.

This part will not help you print with PLA or any other material that require part cooling! For that use the original pp3dp design and open the door to cool the part.

and of course, sources are available on onshape

author: darkherobrine21

description.text: numbers for entrance door , enjoy!

A mount that provides a stable index point for a dial indicator, to aid in bed leveling and end stop setting. Clamps onto the X axis gantry and is quick to attach and detach.  
See instructions for usage.

This clamp press fits to the front of the X axis gantry. It needs an appropriate clearance value to fit snugly. Use the "clamptest" print to determine the proper setting for your printer. The left most clamp is 0, next is 0.1, etc.  
The default parameters are for a Tekton 7169 dial indicator ($16.50 on Amazon). Clamp the mount in position and place the shaft of the dial indicator through the hole.  
The Tekton has a slightly thicker head than the shaft, so it is not possible to get a perfectly snug fit. With the flat base of the shaft sleeve resting on the top of the clamp, however, it is stable enough to provide a consistent reference suitable for z-axis end stop setting. Raise the bed until the end stop switch is triggered and make a note of the setting. Continue raising until the bed touches the extruder (easiest if you are using the plain glass bed as you can see the extruder reflection), and the difference is your z-level height.  
There is too much play for this to be used reliably to level the bed. I hope that with some improvements, it may one day be useful for that function.  
Rotate to print with the clamps up.

description.text:
I like to have organized cable solutions for my personal computers and I am a fan of cable management at all, so why not manage the wires of my Tevo Delta (Little Monster) as well I thought.
And here it is, a bracket to organize all the wires in the original enclosure, no modifications needed. The bracket slips on the space holders on which the sBase is mounted. It might to be a bit to tight, than just grab a 5.5mm drill bit and "clean" the hole.
And there we go! now you may close the box and don't be afraid of missing some wires which you could jam. AND your running wires in this plastic sleeve which runs down to your effector, this is now hold in place, there is no movement at all and your connections will stay in place.
You are able to print this twice, it fits on both sides, left and right. Just unscrew your sBase, slip this over the space holders and screw your sBase back in place - done! Now you may use zip ties to manage all your wires to fit your needs. They will stay in place.

Works great in combination with my LM TMC2100 bracket: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2509605

You are welcome! ;-)

description.text:
These movement trays are very similar to Games Workshop's 25mm base movement trays. I'm using these to play Saga, a tabletop miniature wargame. (https://www.grippingbeast.co.uk/Saga.html)

I used a different cylinder shape to make the holes in the improved version. The older ones used the basic shape and it has a limited number of edges. This made it not a true circle which caused problems with bases that were a little more than 25mm in size. The new "true" circles should handle those a lot better. Also, the improved trays have more options on sizes.

I hope that everyone that uses this design knows that they can separate the bases in Repetier or Cura and print just the ones that they want.

description.text:
I had a pair of halogen lights and an AC transformer which I used to add lights to my CR 10 enclosure. I've been designing things for about a month so it might need some tweaking but I was successful in printing them and I am using two of them in my setup. They provide light and heat for ABS prints. I can go up to 50 C + ambient temp but try to stay below 45 to keep electronics happy.

To make one arm you will need a print of each part (base,arm,light holder and a hole cover) as well as:

2 x rubber washers - i used 5/16 M8 rubber washers, these are placed as shown in the last picture.
2 x M3x20mm and matching nuts - to secure the light unto the light holder part.

There are many knobs you can use but I printed 2 of these https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:769430 by B_EMME3D. Printing one as is for the M6 and resizing down for one M5. I epoxied them unto the the following parts:

1x M5x25mm bolt
1 x M6x13mm bolt

I put old locknuts under the M6 head to lift the bolt up to the brim of the knob before gluing. Lastly use 2 wood screws to secure the base and use a drill bit to pass light cables through enclosure and seal hole with hole cover STL.

author: Col04

description.text:
I had a dream... wow.. stop! Maybe a bit to big words for this project. But I really had a wish - to fit a TMC2100 upgrade inside of the Tevo Delta (Little Monster) enclosure without to modify anything. It should be plug&play as much as possible and here we go:
This bracket slips over the space holders underneath the sBase and holds three external driver boards with TMC2100 installed on each, or any other stepper driver...
I shorten the screws on the fan and on the connector, they were a bit to long for my liking, but you don't need to do this as well.
You may screw the external driver boards with only one screw at the top, than it is possible to unscrew the boards without to unscrew the sBase before.

Screws needed: 3-6 M3 screws with a length of 6mm (same as used for mounting the sBase)

Works great in combination with my LM cable (management) bracket: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2509575

You are welcome! ;-)

description.text: A place where your keys feel comfortable ...

This is a bunch of brackets I made for a RODI water filtration system I built for cleaning my solar panels and cars. The brackets where needed to neatly cram 4 full size 10" filter cartridge holders, 3 RO membranes,a booster pump, 3 res./bypass valves and a bunch of tubing all into a Rubbermaid All Access Organizer storage crate. Although it was tight, it works great and everything comes out of the crate easily for filter changes and servicing. This crate has a front panel that opens as well as top access. The membrane rings (2 per housing) slide snugly over the housings and allow multiple membrane housings to be stacked and zip tied neatly together. The booster pump mounting bracket sits above and in the center between 4 10" filter housings laid out in a rectangle, allowing the 3 RO housings to lay horizontally below the booster pump between the filters. The restricter / bypass valves zip tie to the bracket and the the bracket is zip tied to the wall of the crate.

description.text:
A small enclosure for an HC-12 module with a hole for an SMA bulkhead connector. Plenty of room if you want to add a right-angle pin header with Dupont connections. Top can be glued on or attached with tiny screws, if you have some laying around.

Simply attaches to your model with a couple zip ties or velcro. I use this for a long-distance link from a flight controller running iNav back to a ground station. At the ground station, an HC-12 module receives the signal and sends it directly into a HM-10 Bluetooth LE module. The Bluetooth module connects to my Android tablet running EZ-GUI to complete the link.

These pieces are a scale-accurate representation of the peptide backbone of a protein.

Another DJI Phantom 7th channel knob for moving the gimble pitch via the hole under the transmitter that moves the pot for controlling pitch on a camera gimble. There are a bunch of solutions like this one, but I made  this one when i first added a gimble to the Phantom because I didn't want to modify anything doing it.  This is held in place by engaging the flat tip into the 7th channel pot and then push the other end of the support bracket into the unused hole next to the 7th channel hole on the bottom of the transmitter firm enough to hold the knob in place. Simply pull the bracket out of the hole to remove it.

description.text:
Die beliebte Fühleraufbewahrung geht in die nächste Runde. Die Version Nummer 3 beinhaltet viele Inovationen und ist zudem extrem kompakt. In diesem Fühlerhalter befinden sich sechs kleine Magnete (Ø5x2mm), die perfekten halt an einer magnetischen Fläche bieten und ebenso das Stapeln ermöglichen. Die eigentliche Fühler wird im inneren des Halters optimal geschützt und von zwei Klemmen am Herausrutschen gehindert. Durch die großzügige Bohrung im Inneren lassen sich auch dicke Thermofühler mit dieser Aufbewahrung kombinieren. Außen auf der Spule lässt sich jedes Kabel bequem aufwickeln und fixieren.

Further Information:
http://www.wlanthermo-shop.de/
https://www.grillsportverein.de/forum/threads/wlanthermo-mini-3d-druck-gehaeuse-fuehleraufnahme-variante-crow.262108/

title: Super Nintendo SNES Controller Case for Raspberry Pi Zero Retropie

description.text:
I love the NES Pi Zero controllers, and wanted to try my hand at a SNES version. Unfortunately the placement of two of the screw holes mean that the Pi Zero can't be flush with the front of the controller, so the ports are recessed a bit into the back. This workaround means that the complete controller is about 8mm thicker than a standard SNES controller. It loses some of the classical slimness of the SNES controller, but is a pretty comfortable fit for adult hands.

There are two models here. One with built-in supports that should work pretty well for most users, and one that you'll need to use your own supports on.

This model was designed to be a perfect fit with an original SNES controller top, and requires no modification of the top piece, PCB, buttons, etc. Everything should go together pretty smoothly, except for the pins for the L/R triggers. Those need to be trimmed about 2mm shorter. This was necessary to help keep the lower shell as thin as possible.

Wile it isn't a remix, this project was heavily inspired by bfesser's NES version. If you haven't checked that out yet, I highly recommend it. - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1635363

Edit: 1.2 update adds a little extra support to the screw hole posts.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10

Notes:

Supports are optional, depending on which version of the model you chose. This should print pretty nicely with any typical print settings.

For more details on setting up the Pi, check out this guide: https://howchoo.com/g/zdqxnzblmzm/gamepad-zero-a-raspberry-pi-retro-gaming-rig-in-an-nes-controller

Everything is about the same, except for two notes:

  1. The red and yellow wires should be swapped for the SNES controller.
  2. Use "0,0,1,0,0,0" during step 15 instead of "0,0,2,0,0,0"

This lets me mount my iPhone (with Speck case attached) to my tripod for time-lapse photography.

Update: Use the iPod_Tripod_Mount3 file - I shortened the legs and beefed up the frame on the bottom a bit to prevent breakage. I also rotated it into the correct orientation for printing. 1) If you're using the original iPod Tripod Mount2 file, rotate the part... sorry I modeled it laying down. If you rotate it so the legs point upwards, you shouldn't need to apply supports.
2) Print the part. Be sure to go slow on the bridging and apply some cooling technique (fan or go slow) on the legs.
3) Insert a 1/4-20 nut. It should be pretty snug.
4) Screw the part onto a tripod.
5) Slide your iPhone in - NOTE: I designed this to work with my Speck case attached, so it will be a sloppy fit if you just use a bare iPhone.
6) Loop a rubber band over the phone, using the "ears" on the part to secure it.
7) Enjoy your iPhone on a tripod!

comments.text: Note, there's a lot of geometry problems with the "iPod Tripod Mount 3.stl" file.  Lots of faces that are almost co-planar but not quite. This is especially true between the base and where the arms start.  This makes for a print that is very weak at those junctions, as the printer is essentially printing multiple parts, just really close to each other.

In the little actual part testing I have done, I found that trying to squeeze the legs together can cause them to crack, but the cracks form between layers, not between parts.  Any pointers in making this a better part are much appreciated!

title: Flow Bench cylinder and intake air horn example

description.text: If you work with race engines you know that building flow bench rigging is a pain. Using a 3D printer  for cylinder bore and port fitments can allow many variables to be tested in a short period of time. This is an example of a Nissan VQ V6 race head setup. By using all thread, nuts and a  bottom plate, the head can be held by the cylinder rig alone.  Also note the valve controller uses a 3D printed fork to move 2 valves during testing.

title: AO-10x Bracket for pablogil's Full Graphic LCD Case

description.text: This bracket will allow you to mount the Full Graphic LCD case to your Mendelmax  / Ao-10x style Upper Gantry frame (Should work with a TAZ too for that matter) I've included two mounting styles, one will require support to print. There is also a connection cover backplate, though that particular piece as designed will be a pain to print. It's there if you want to attempt it anyways.

The tabless version should print fine without support. uses M5 mounting screws. The tabbed version will require support,  The backplate mounts with M3 screws and sandwiches the mount and the LCD case itself. It will rewquire massive amounts of support to print, but most of the support marks will be hidden internally, so I think it still serves its decorative purpose adequatly. I plan on making an additional cable routing piece once I figure out how everything needs to route once I have this printed and on the machine.

Just a quick bracket to hold an hour meter. I recommend installing one on your 3D printer    so you can tell just how many hours are on the bearings, belts etc. Important for any kind of   record keeping or maintenance program. This meter fits in a 50mm hole. There are some issues with the .stl I will fix soon. In the meantime it does print just fine.

Uses 4 608zz bearings on 78mm by 120mm centers. Pieces joined by two M3x8mm cap-head screws at each corner. Partially countersunk screw holes with support cylinder to avoid sag. OSHW logo on each end, cut-outs add a little flare while reducing material cost. Approx. 35g PLA with 1mm skin and 50% infill.

title: Presto Pegasus Symmetry R5 part: Shock-proof GoPro Session Mount (V2)

description.text:
This is a 3D printing file for Presto Pegasus Symmetry R5's accessory part: Shock-proof GoPro Session Actioncam mount. (Fits both GoPro Session & GoPro 5 Session)

This is not a original stock design but optimised for TPU printing (designed by Symmetry R5 pilot C.N. OH aka Ryan FPV). It has a shock-proof feature which will protect your GoPro Session even more. 20mm spacer may be needed to screw the session mount tightly.

This GoPro mount is compatible with Presto Pegasus Symmetry series frames.

It is mounted with only two M3 screws on Symmetry R5 frame. No strap is required.

Recommended to print with TPU with 100% scale.

This file is free to use except for commercial use.

  • This file is designed/provided by Ryan FPV

author: jackStarbuck

description.text:
I have a Dyson DC 16 animal. For all the things its great for, it doesn't mate well with the diameter of the nozzle on those vacuum sealing bags (like what you store spare Duvets/Pillows in) meaning you never get much air removed as the seal is terrible.

This clicks into the Dyson perfectly and makes a much better sear around the air port on the vacuum bags.

Printer:

Vector 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Better Seal

If you want a better seal, grab a sheet of 2mm thick self adhesive foam from eBay, stuck this around the side that mates with the vacuum bag and trim the excess off with a very sharp knife.

Too Much Powaaaa

Sadly, the seal is so good, the vacuum (mine at least) thinks the nozzle is blocked and actually starts and stops the motor in an effort to allow whatever is "blocking" the nozzle to fall out.

To Alleviate this you need to drill 4x 5.5mm holes around the body of the adaptor. This allows air to bypass and get into the vacuum. Its JUST enough to make the thing not comp[lain, but not enough to affect the compression power of the vac bag. For example, a 4.5mm hole didn't work for me, 5.5 was perfect.

This design is still a Work-In-Progress because I have not printed it myself yet. I would like too, but my printer needs to be fixed from a bad failed print.

When I joined the 3D Printing world a few months ago I kept seeing 3D "Things" That were "Low Poly this" or "Low Poly that". It confused me because I thought it was some kind of plastic. I said to myself "How can the tell you what kind of plastic the virtual model is?" Then I learned that it meant low polygons, which meant less detailed. I don't completely see the point, other than that processing is faster, and it can give the design a cool look.

https://youtu.be/jck6ABsEEjo

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5b1372dd0a277fe63e4f8212/w/e2deb504daa97bb80e618038/e/aa9611e8959efbd7885cd655

I made this bracelet in onShape. I made them for me and my girl friend. If you are willing to log into onShape you can tinker with the original design and customize it.

The teal bracelet was made with polysmooth PLA and put in an improvised alcohol vapor bath (humidifier with plastic bag over it.) It was printed with a .2 mm layer height at 210 degrees on my Prusa Original.

The yellow was printed with Hatchbox 3D yellow PLA on my Prusa Original with a .05 mm layer height at 215 degrees.

description.text:
This laser cut Raspberry Pi enclosure design features light pipes for the status LEDs and obscures the T-slots for a nice clean looking enclosure. All off board connectors are accessable with the top off and you can use standard ribbon cable connectors through the case to hook up the expansion header as well. Spacing of the top layers have been adjusted so these should be compatible with pi plates when they become availiable with minimal additional hardware. UPDATE:
The design has been updated to support both the models of the Raspberry Pi board (A & B) and include better standoffs. Updates thanks to Thingiverse user RoboLemur for the design updates. Black acrylic kits are available here:
http://nvy.gd/Lv1ESn And a limited number of translucent purple acrylic kits are available here:
http://nvy.gd/Lv2Ox9

Cut on black lines, vector etch on red. Main enclosure parts are 3mm acrylic and the light pipe parts are 1.5mm acrylic and the new standoffs are 3/32" Delrin. Uses 4 M3-16 bolts for assembly. Full instructions and additional pics are availiable on my site:
http://www.built-to-spec.com/blog/kit-instructions/raspberry-pi-enclosure-assembly-instructions

title: Willys MB 1/10 drivetrain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A printable drivetrain for a Willys MB Jeep. It's fully printable, no donor car needed. The axles fit between frame and suspension leaves and the drive shaft is on the right side, giving it a very realistic appearance.

It has, however, a few limitations:
-Designed for a N20 gear motor (not only slow, but also very low power). Forget jumps and hill climbs with this motor.
-The turn radius is really big, like the original thing.
-It has no differentials, it's permanent all wheel drive
-Rims need to be glued to the axles, might have unbalanced wheels

That said, it gives a working car, and replacing the current gearbox with a bigger motor is on my to-do list. As you can see the frame mounting is not perfectly designed, as I plan to change the ossum frame to a U-profile frame - for weight and stability.

Printer:

Qidi Avatar IV

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Prints fine in ABS, and should go with PETG, too. PLA it too brittle most likely.
I printed all parts in ABS, except for the suspension that I printed in PETG. All parts are oriented the best way to print. The hollow housings need a lot of support but no cleaning post-printing on the inside - which can be a pain with these small details.

A list of all needed parts:

  • 1 servo: SG90 9g
  • 1 motor: N20 gear motor
  • 14 bearings: MR84 (8mm outer diameter, 3mm width, 4mm inner diameter)
    7 for the front axle
    2 for the gearbox
    5 for the rear axle
  • 33 screws: M2x10 (normal head, not 'flat head/counter sunk')
    12 for the suspension
    8 for the front axle
    4 for the gearbox
    8 for the rear axle
    1 for the servo horn/steering
  • 33 nuts: M2
  • 6 pins: 2x10 (2mm diameter, 10mm length)
    3 for the front axle
    2 for the gearbox
    1 for the rear axle
  • copper/steel: 1.5x15 (1.5mm diameter, 15mm length (source: cable))
    (steering, bend it)
    -4x steel wire: 0.8x10 (0.8mm diameter, 10mm length (source: garden wire))
    (clamp the axles to the suspension leaves)

Body, chassis and more: By ossum (look at remix source)
Body tub: By Anarchy3D 'Body (Ultra Realistic Ossum Jeep Remix)', the gearbox fits there
Rims and tyres: Originally by bre4, I used my own mod here (look at remix source)
Front bumper: my mod
Rear bumper: By Intashu (look at remix source)

Bending of a copper or steel wire for steering: I should add a proper picture, but I'll do it with ASCII for now:

###                      ###
  #                      #
  ########################
         # #
         # #
         # #
         ###

The topmost ends go though the holes in the steering blocks, the horizontal part should be below the hinges to avoid collisions with the suspension, and somewhere in the middle is a loop that is just wide enough to allow a M2 screw to fit in between.
The servo horn will have a M2 screw secured with a nut.
Upon moving the servo this screw moves in a circular path, resulting in up- and down-movement in said loop, and horizontal moving to the left and right, steering the wheels.
There's no servo saver, but at the current vehicle speed a servo with plastic gears is just fine.

Mount the leaves to the brackets, and glue the brackets to the frame, at the place the original brackets would go. You should see the original mounting holes on both sides of the brackets partly. When dried remove the leaves again to mount them to the axle.
Put the axle upside-down, with the flat sides on top, and put a suspension leaf on one side, with the ends hanging down. Then take a wire, bend it to a U-shape, as wide as the leaf. Put it on the leaf, bend the two ends around the axle in a U-shape coming up to the leaf on the other side of the axle. Then twist(*) the ends above the leaf gently with pliers and you're done. Repeat it on the other side, and on the other axle and then mount it back to the brackets on the frame again.

(*): Don't twist too hard, as twisted wire can create very strong forces. And you don't want a tight fit, as some play is necessary to allow different compression on every side.

title: AntiVibration Speaker Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hey

This is an Anti-Vibration Speaker Stand mostly for small to Medium Monitor Speakers.
It's all Printable, sure it would be much better when using any steel/aluminum Tubes. But whatsoever.

Dimensions: ~200x160x230mm (LxWxH)

PS: The FlexPart might need a little Support, but sometimes it's Hard to remove Flex support. You can see on one of the Photos, that looks like when not using any support. It was okay for me since this side of the part is not visible.

UPDATE: Added 2 Spacers (5mm and 8mm) So you can put 2 Spacers in the back on the 2 Tubes and the Speakers will have a slightly Angle from back to front. You can actually change it by yourself in the slicer when changing the Z Scale!

UPDATE2: It should be possible to Stack those Stands since the Flex parts on each other will have enough Grip to stay in position!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

~20-30%

Notes:

IMPORTANT!!!!
You need to Print the 8 Anti-Vibrations Parts ("Buffer_FlexPart.stl") out of NinjaFlex or similar flexible Filament.
I do not recommend SoftPLA since it's not that flexible than Ninjaflex as an example.
Don't Print it too fast. let's say around 20mm/s.

I recommend to Print the Tubes on 100% Infill and the Bottom and Top Part at least on 20%.
I designed it in Fusion360 for a friend, because he bought some new speakers and I thought let's have some Fun and Design something nice!

author: stonecoldfx

description.text: Kamasutra cookie cutter

Printer:

k8200
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6Czz38e6IAP
V2 now available: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:511668

Non-Commerical = No Printing and Selling
============
Please pay attention and respect the creative commons license these files were released under. This means the files are available for personal use only. For those without a printer, all the parts are available for purchase at: http://shop.hovership.com If others continue to disrespect the license I will no longer be sharing any future designs.

The Hovership MHQ is designed for portable FPV flying and capturing video with smaller cameras like a Mobius or GoPro. The frame is an H-Quadcopter layout with foldable arms and a vibration isolated layer for the flight controller and camera. FPV through tight spaces: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a8d_lyni_Lc
First FPV flight: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tTA2C6hPz_w
First flight from one of my beta testers:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f932Kqe02Z4
Motors, ESCs, Power Distrubtion boards, and Printed Kits Available: http://shop.hovership.com

Suggested motors:
  • Hovership H2204X: http://shop.hovership.com/h2204x-2300kv-brushless-motor/
  • Cobra 2204 (2300kv)
  • SunnySky X2204S
  • RCX 1804
  • Lumenier FX2206-13
  • Tiger MN-1806
  • Turnigy Multistar 1704
    • Props: 5" max ESCs: 12a, 2mm bullet connectors Battery: 1300-1500mAh 3-cell, Zippy compact 1500mAh are nice and flat. Frame Weight: ~133g with all hardware including motor screws The control deck can fit a controller with a max hole spacing of 45mm. However, it is recommended to use a smaller (lighter) board. The standoffs for the top plates should ideally be 20mm or less. This will require a controller with right angle header pins. Flight controllers that meet this criteria:
  • KK2.1HC: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=39791
  • Acro Naze: http://abusemark.com/store/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=1&products_id=38
  • Flip 2.0: http://witespyquad.gostorego.com/flight-controllers/flip-2-0.html
  • Flip 32: http://witespyquad.gostorego.com/flight-controllers/the-flip32.html
  • OpenPilot CC3D: http://www.readymaderc.com/store/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=76_156&products_id=2152
  • Tau Labs Sparky: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/phoenixpilot/sparky/phoenixpilot/Yw-1yUFcoiE/O80P1omQKNMJ
  • DJI Naza Lite
    • If you must use a controller with straight pins, you will need standoffs that are 30-40mm tall. With this option the battery should be mounted between the 2 top plates as to avoid the copter being too top heavy.

UPDATE 06-12-2014
Added a V2 landing gear. This version has a "rib" to strengthen the part for rough landings. UPDATE 05-01-2014
Added a V3 arm. This has the motor mounting holes rotated so that motors with M3 screws can use the groove in the arm to run the wires straight down the arm instead of coming out the side. UPDATE 03-08-2014
Modified both arm designs to be 4mm longer. The added length improves prop clearance from the center plates. UPDATE 03-01-2014
Added a version 2 arm design. I noticed that with motors using the M2 bolts, the way the wires come out of the motor is not ideal. I added a groove to the arm so that the wires can run straight down the arm instead of off the side. UPDATE 02-23-2014
I added baseplates and control decks for 6mm and 9mm vibration dampeners to allow more sourcing options for this part. See instructions for links to suggested dampeners. I have tested the fit but have not flown with these new sizes.

Hardware needed
============
Motors:
  • 16x 6mm M2 or M3 bolts - depending on which motors you use
    Arms:
  • 4x 18mm M3 bolts
  • 4x 20mm M3 bolts
  • 8x M3 nylon washers
  • 8x M3 thin metal washers
  • 8x M3 lock nuts
    Landing gear:
  • 4x 12mm M3 bolts
  • 4x M3 lock nuts
    Standoffs (to separate the upper decks):
  • The two deck plates that are separated with these standoffs have holes for 8 but I found that 6 was enough, 3 in opposing corners.
  • For a flush mounted controller with right angle pins, 6x 15mm or 20mm female threaded standoffs/spacers.
  • For a flight controller with vertical pins, 6x 30mm female threaded standoffs/spacers
  • 12x 5mm M3 bolts
    Vibration dampeners:
  • ATG small grey (7mm hole mounting): http://www.goodluckbuy.com/4-pcs-atg-anti-vibration-sphere-av-ball-high-elastic-rubber-ball-dual-head-anti-vibration-for-ptz-small.html or http://www.aliexpress.com/item/ATG-AV-Ball-High-Elastic-Rubber-Ball-Dual-head-Anti-vibration-for-PTZ-Small-Grey-color/1023411887.html
  • 6mm: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=37447 or http://www.aliexpress.com/item/9mm-M3-High-Elastic-Rubber-Ball-Dual-head-Anti-vibration-for-PTZ-4piece-Pack-Free-Shipping/1023197247.html
  • 9mm: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=40615 or http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=40614

    Print Settings

  • I have only printed these parts with ABS which have held up well in crashes. PLA might not hold up as well but these parts are all cheap to print replacements for.
  • Arms and base: print at 80% infill. Depending on the abilities of your printer, you might need supports for the base model. There are recessed clearance holes on the underside for the 6 vibration dampeners.
  • Deck and arm plates: 30% infill

    Print Quantities

  • Base: 1x (pick 6,7 or 9mm depending on the size of vibration dampeners being used)
  • Arms: 4x - file named v2 includes a groove for the wires to run down the arm on motors that use M2 bolts. v3 has the mounting holes rotated for motors with M3 bolts to use the groove for wires to run down.
  • Arm Plate: 2x
  • Deck control: 1x (pick 6,7 or 9mm depending on the size of vibration dampeners being used)
  • Deck cam: 1x
  • Landing: 2x

    Build Instructions

    Full build guide available here: http://www.hovership.com/guides/

So I now have printed about 3 of these.... I can't for the life of me get one strong enough to fly well. All of mine have way too much flex, specifically, diagonally. I have printed in ABS with 35% Honeycomb infill, 65% honeycomb and 50% rectilinear. Then I printed one more base plate in PLA with (IIRC) 50% infill. Infact, I found the 35% honeycomb to be just as torsion-ally (diagonally) strong as the 65%, yet significantly lighter (and quicker to print).
What are you guys doing that makes this thing strong enough? How many of you are flying with true FPV systems?
My set up is:
4x RCX 1804 (Also tried 4x Maytech)
Gemfan 5030, nylon and carbonfiber props
4x Maytech SimonK ESC's
KK2.1.5 FC
3s Battery
Boscam 5.8ghs 400mw vTX (also have flown with a 200mw Immerson vTX)
Mobius w/Video out
I REALLY want to fly a good mini-h 3d printed quad, but this one seems to be disappointing me. I might just go back to my G10 and CF frames.... Its unfortunate because I love showing off my 3d printed awesomeness =D...
Any help or ideas to get this thing flyable?
comments.author: Jwmflying14

comments.text:
I print at 75% rectilinear on the base and arms. Yes there is some flex but I don't find it to ruin the flight performance. There is a remix of my base plate that allows you to add a carbon rod down the center. I haven't tried it myself.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:302159http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
I am using a 500mw 5.8 tx, CCD camera and a replay xd mini all at the same time. See the new video I just posted today above.

I just thought I'd add something for anyone that had a problem finding the standoffs like I did.
I had all the metric screws, nuts, etc. but couldn't find a the black M3x20mm standoffs that are used when you buy the kit or hardware kit except from a couple of chinese places.
Decided to try and print my own and turned out really well.
You can get them (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335435)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
And I'm not trying to take away from Hoverships business or awesome design at all, just trying to help people out who cant find these.
I weighed the standoffs, and my scale only has 1g increments. I weighed 1 of the standoffs and it came out to 0g. All 6 of them weighed in at 4g. I am not sure what the aluminum ones weighed but these seem really light to me.

title: Snap Button to attach  Big Max Accessory Pouch  to Blade Trolley

description.text:
For me, the "BigMax Blade" is one of the best Golf-Trolleys available.
It can be folded in 3 moves very flat so it fits behind a drivers-seat.
And it is affordable for almost everyone.

unfortunately it does not have an accessory pouch beneath the handle and BigMax does not sell one for this model.
But BigMax sells a Pouch for the Z360 Trolley with 6 snap-buttons to attach it.
As the Blade does not have snap-buttons, I've created them to be printed in 3D.

No. 1 is for the front, No. 2 for the middle and No.3 for the rear button.
1 & 3 can be screwed with the existing screws of the Blade-Trolley, No. 2 is attached with ordinary volcra-tape or cable-tie.
Just print No.1 and 2 twice each
No.3 is not symetric and has to be printed once as downloaded and once mirrored so the snap-button is positionioned at the inner side.

have fun!

title: D-Bot Stepper-mounted Z-axis Endstop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a custom bracket that can be mounted above the D-Bot's Z-axis steppers to stop the gantry from lowering beyond 40mm above the stepper. With the particular combination of parts on my build, this stops the gantry at about 325mm of Z height, slightly beyond the spec 320mm.

This is to solve the problem of having multiple Z steppers get out of alignment with each other. I'm running three, which just compounds the potential problem.

To align the steppers, I essentially z-home to zero, then lower the bed 310mm. At that point, I turn down the stepper current low enough to cause easy skipping. It then lowers the bed another 30mm, which lowers all three motors to the Z-stops evenly. Then the current is turned back up, and the bed Z-homed again.

This ensures bed leveling adjustments and mesh compensation stay accurate over time. Even if your controller can't be set up to do it automatically, you could do it manually when you want to verify they're all in alignment.

Installing is simple -- they're notched to fit around the threaded rod and the coupler, so all you need to do is unscrew your stepper, replace the 8mm M3s with 12mm, and screw this back in in the appropriate orientation to catch your z-axis nut bracket or rail. (Basically orient it to face inwards, it'll fit in any orientation relative to the existing motor mount.)

One warning on these -- depending on your motor torque, its possible you can stretch / damage your flexible couplings if you're using the D-bot recommended ones that look like aluminum springs. They're not strong enough to resist linear extension pressures. (Its a problem even without these stops being used for alignment, as too much roller friction can cause them to stretch a bit during moves.) I'd recommend using solid couplings instead of "flexible" ones. (Ie, if the ones you are using look like the ones in the photos above, you may have issues if you're running higher torque levels... ask me how I know...)

comments.author: anoldguy

comments.text: I'm using 8x8 lead screws, and while the movement isn't exactly fast, its not any slower than I would've expected. There's a reason they're not used for the X/Y axis! I did find I had to run the power pretty high to get the speeds I have. I run with a 600mm/min maximum on the Z, and it takes running 1.5 amp to do that without skipping. That's why I have to drop the power levels when I do the auto-leveling, as I can damage the lead screw couplings. (In fact, I run a combination of these stops and clamping shaft collars (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0063KPT16) to make it "safe" to do the alignment blind. These parts provide the reference height, and the clamps on the lead screws actually stop it without putting too much extension pressure on the couplings. (Basically, with it all the way down on these stops, I raised the bed .5mm, and then clamped the collars in place.)

description.text:
This is a remix of Dant3C0rp's pendant wand. It's been resized to 11 inches (279.4 mm) and laid out for printing. The wand printed out great in about 3 hours. The inserts are a little big so I'm adjusting their size down and reprinting them now. I'll update the model once I find a good size for it

Depending on your printer the filler pieces may be too big. They were on mine but could have been sanded to fit. I've included an alternate filler that is a little smaller if you don't want to sand them down for a tight fit.

Assembly I just filled the pockets with 5 minute epoxy and then placed the filler piece in on all three parts. It looks really nice.

The kids have been playing with this for a few days now and I've had to fix it twice. I'd recommend higher shell than normal and a little more infill if you are planning to let kids play with it.

10-5-2017
Added a version without the filler in the main file. Since the tolerance is a little high on the larger fillers I recommend just printing the no filler version and using the smaller filler

title: Panic Button with attiny85 and RCSwitch 433Mhz module

description.text:
I've built this panic button just for emergency, in my house i've set up a domotic system with arduino, basically this button send a 433 code that the base can receive and do whatever you need to do.

it's battery operated with a 12v battery and a 220ohm resistor so the voltage for the circuit it's around 4.5v

the attiny85 it's an "arduino" but for really simple operations, due to low memory available, it must be programmed with an arduino uno or 2009, i'll link the guide...
https://create.arduino.cc/projecthub/arjun/programming-attiny85-with-arduino-uno-afb829

attiny85 as pwn pin on 0 and 1.

https://it.aliexpress.com/item/433mhz-rf-Transmitter-and-Receiver-superheterodyne-UHF-ASK-remote-control-Module-with-Antenna-Kit-small-size/32651427149.html?spm=a2g0y.search0104.3.1.vOC4ja&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_2_10152_10065_10151_10068_5430020_5410020_10304_10307_10137_10060_10302_10155_10154_10333_10334_10056_10335_10055_10336_10054_10059_10332_100031_10099_5400020_10103_10102_10052_10053_10107_10050_10142_10051_5380020_10326_5390020_10084_10083_5370020_10080_10082_10081_10177_10110_10111_5420020_10112_10113_10114_10312_10313_10184_10314_10078_10079_10073-10333,searchweb201603_16,ppcSwitch_5&btsid=f9199dc4-d6d2-4eae-aa62-303e2f7e34dd&algo_expid=49bebf02-9737-42a7-818f-c760868f8bca-0&algo_pvid=49bebf02-9737-42a7-818f-c760868f8bca&transAbTest=ae803_1

a couple of leds and a push switch
the holes are 5mm for leds and 12mm for the switch

the button just activate the circuit that sends signal immediately in a loop.

//CODE

include

RCSwitch mySwitch = RCSwitch();

void setup() {
// Transmitter is connected to Attiny Pin PB3 <--
// That is physical pin2
mySwitch.enableTransmit(3);
pinMode(1,OUTPUT);
pinMode(0,OUTPUT);
}

void loop() {
mySwitch.send(123123,24);

for(int i=0;i<255;i++){
analogWrite(0,i);
delay(2);
}
digitalWrite(0,LOW);
for(int i=0;i<255;i++){
analogWrite(1,i);
delay(2);
}
digitalWrite(1,LOW);

delay(100);

for(int i=0;i<255;i++){
analogWrite(1,i);
delay(2);
}
digitalWrite(1,LOW);
for(int i=0;i<255;i++){
analogWrite(0,i);
delay(2);
}
digitalWrite(0,LOW);

}

//END

The lib: https://github.com/sui77/rc-switch

author: matghir

description.text:
I tell people in IRC how I calibrate my X and Y steps/mm, and they immediately ask for a .stl - so here it is.
A 100 x 100 x 1 mm hollow square, for calibrating your X and Y Axis steps/mm, and for squaring your Y axis.
Print it. Measure It. Use http://calculator.josefprusa.cz/ to determine your correct X and Y steps/mm. Use a try square to determine how far out of square your Y axis is.

comments.text: Thanks, I am using this as final calibration verification
comments.author: mp3_e46

comments.text: Measuring with calipers is a good first (or second) step, to eliminate obvious calibration errors (incorrect microstepping settings, wrong belt/pulley description, etc), but nothing beats measuring an actual print for dealing with belt stretch, etc...

description.text:
Summer's almost over, but it's still hot. It's still muggy.

This fan prints all as a single piece, except for one small spacer that gets inserted to tighten up the assembly. Get fancy and print yours with a change of color (or two) mid-print.

https://youtu.be/UZylBya21Ck

(For some reason, Thingiverse is refusing to display the rendered FAN.STL. Not to worry - the file is there to download and it is correct.)

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

none

After printing, make sure all bits of the raft are removed completely. Gently separate the blades of the fan at the end. At the hub, if you squash all of the blades together, it will mostly break everything free. To completely free each blade, start with the blade on back side with the nub and rotate it out. There are internal stops on each blade to keep them from rotating too far - each blade should only pivot out by a blade's width. Repeat with each blade. Finally, press all of the blades together and then clip the little spacer over the exposed section of axle between the blades and the nub. This keeps the blades pressed together so that the internal stops operate properly.

When everything is broken free and operating smoothly, you should be able to snap the fan open and closed like in the video.

description.text: This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26524. Wanted 4 fins and a bit more like the V2 rocket of WW2.
I sliced it with Slic3r 10.2.  0.2 layer height and a 40% honeycomb infill. It did not need any rafts or support on my Makerbot Replicator 2. Takes about 1h:30m to print @ 50mm ps speed.

This printed part requires many journeys of the nozzle and then, it is very prone to form blobs and oozing

You can use it to adjust your Retraction, Coast to End and Wiping settings to get rid of them

There are three designs

  • a tall towerthat can be split in 6 different setting parts to use with Simplify3D
  • another one for its use in a single fast printing designed to save time and filament
  • the whole circle as show in the photo

====================================================================
Este diseño requiere de muchos viajes por parte de la boquilla extrusora, y es muy propensa a tener rezumados del filamentos (oozing) y burbujas (blobs)

Se puede usar para mejorar los ajustes de retracción, coast to end y wipe (en S3D) para mejorar estos aspectos

title: Front hull with embedded head light

description.text:
This is a remix of the file " Chassis_2_V1" for Staind's RC Tank.

I wanted to add some headlights and I found a cool looking USB bike light for about 6 Euro on Ebay. It is somewhat oversized, but I like this asymmetrical "hull mounted laser gun" look of the light embedded in the hull.
The light is held in place by a M3x5 screw, which is a bit of a hassle to unscrew. I recommend removing the right motor, to avoid breaking your fingers. ;-)

The next step is to replace the LED driver which requires to push a little button on the back plate of the light to switch it on and off. A constant current driver operating from 6 V to 15 V should do nicely for powering it directly from the main battery and to add an RC switch to control the light by the transmitter.

I printed the chassis without supports using PETG and lots of cooling.

Here is the url of the light:

http://www.ebay.de/itm/MINI-USB-5000lm-XML-T6-LED-Fahrradlampe-Licht-Fahrradbeleuchtung-Fahrradlicht/142130574338?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=441208015357&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649

The same light is also available from AliExpress. The size is 28 mm x 28 mm.

Edit:

2017-12-16

Added a back cover for the USB bike light.
It uses the screws from the original back cover of the light and it has an opening for the wires to the PCB which drives the LED. The PCB is glued into place in the ring on the inner side of the cover plate.

2017-10-18

Made some measurements of the lights current draw and power consumption:

Input 5V from USB Power Bank
LED current:
mode 1: 0,3 A
mode 2: 0,6 A
mode 3: 1,15 A

So when powered from a USB source, the LED runs with a forward current up to 1,15 A. I personally would aim for something between 0,75 A and 1 A. Just to be sure. The difference in brightness is not really that great.

After removing the build in driver and control board with the bothersome 3 mode switch (which prevents the light from being controlled via an RC switch) I coupled the LED with this constant current LED driver:

http://www.dx.com/de/p/3-6v-9v-800ma-regulated-ic-circuit-board-for-cree-and-ssc-leds-4-pack-3256#.Weee2DtpGpp

It says the output is 925 mA constant current, but like with all cheap Chinese circuit boards the actual value might be somewhat different:

Input voltage | input current | Power Consumption | LED Current

4,5 V | 0,59 A | 2,6 W | 0,78 A
5,5 V | 0,48 A | 2,68 W | 0,78 A
6,5 V | 0,42 A | 2,7 W | 0,78 A
8 V | 0,4 A | 2,73 W | 0,77 A
9 V | 0,3 A | 2,9 W | 0,8 A
9,5 V | 0,43 A | 4,14 W | 1,1 A
10 V | 0,51 A | 5 W | 1,28 A

So between about 4 V to about 9 V input voltage the driver gives a reliably stable constant current of about 0,8 A which I consider a good trade off between brightness, power consumption and heat generation -> long-time safety for the LED. Perfect for powering the driver with a 2S LiPo.
I would not recommend running the LED with 1,28 A @ 10 V input voltage, as it might reduce the LEDs lifespan.

comments.author: Oger

comments.text:
Ist zwar noch nicht Wochenende, aber man ist ja selber neugierig. Ich habe die LED mit dem Standardtreiber and 5V USB und dann mit dem anderen Treiber von DX gemessen.
Das sollte so funktionieren. Mit 2S läuft die LED stabil mit ca. 0,8 A im Gesamten Bereich von Akku voll bis Akku entladen. 3S wird nicht gehen, da steigt der Strom zu weit an, bzw. man müsste dann die SMD Widerstände auf dem treiber anpassen, um den Strom zu senken.
comments.author: Monky

comments.text: I am intending to run on 3s, so I suppose I need a different LED driver board?  Has anyone had a chance to get this running yet?  I would be fine tbh with replacing the button with a 3-position toggle switch or the like if that would work...  a toggle could easily be mounted on the hull in a convenient place for me to switch it on/off
comments.author: Oger

comments.text: You could use the BEC line of the ESC which is not being used to power the receiver. It will give you regulated 6V 1A from the 3S Lipo. The driver from DX draws about 0,5 A at 6 V and gives a nice and stable output of 0,78 A to the LED in the lamp.
